title: R42562
content: The Moving to Work (MTW) demonstration program, created in 1996 by Congress, allows HUD and local PHAs to test alternative policies for housing assistance. Over 30 PHAs participate in MTW, managing billions in funding to support low-income families. The future of MTW is uncertain, with calls for changes before the 2018 expiration of current agreements. Critics argue that MTW agencies have too much flexibility without clear understanding of the program's impact. The Moving to Work Demonstration Program, authorized in 1996, allows PHAs to test new approaches for providing housing assistance to low-income families. The program aims to reduce costs, promote self-sufficiency, and increase housing choices. Up to 30 PHAs can participate in the program through a competitive process, with evaluations conducted for up to 15 agencies to identify successful models. The program's legislative guidelines are broad, allowing agencies flexibility in developing and testing approaches to assisted housing.
